rr4gnduf8uABIXeXdiY5vw.text: The Bottom Line: Good quality and service, but the portions are on the smaller side.Try:Grilled Chicken Burrito BowlPro:The service is fast and friendly, and the restaurant itself has a good vibe. It has a slightly chic-er take on Chipotle.The food itself is pretty good! Don't expect authentic Mexican, but it is pretty good for what it is. Good flavors and seasoning, and all the right ingredients. I'd come back for sure.Con:The portions are a bit small for the price.

lczgIsRlglJPv9by_h0BkA.text: Mex Out is one of the better Mexican joints in Singapore.I agree with Michelle that their food tends on the salty side (still) but it wasn't as overpowering as described in her review. Perhaps they got the message and took the salt down a notch, but just a notch - so maybe my burrito had only 2 days worth of daily recommended allowance for sodium but it was still a worthwhile treat.I had a large pork burrito with cheese and sour cream (an extra $0.50 each) with a side order of big chips which comes with your choice of salsa and a canned drink or water. Everything clocked in at just under $20 which I've begrudgingly resigned to accept as the norm around these parts.Service is quick and courteous with a lot of comfortable seating options inside and outside.The queue can be quite long during peak lunch hours so come during off-peak times to enjoy your burrito in peace.

photos.caption: Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore. Large burrito with a side of big chips, salsa, and drink all for under $20,a bargain by SG standards!

-vaXhM9GKZ-kOwKZk9R-Nw.text: Came here for dinner on a Wed evening, it was fairly quiet.  Decor inside was quite pleasant and the service staff were very friendly and helpful.  My girlfriend had a mini burrito.  Good flour tortilla, really yummy rice and the chicken was really juicy and tasty (which is surprising given that in its cube form it looks really plain).  The downside - the burrito wasn't wrapped properly.  The moment she unwrapped it from the foil, one part of it had already become undone and the rice was spilling out.  A far cry from Chipotle (or any other) burritos in the States where it's wrapped tighter than a peranakan grandma's hair bun.  I had 3 Tacos.  Paid extra $2 to have beef barbacoa in one and Carne (also beef) in another, and the 3rd was pulled pork (which would normally be regular price - it's extra $2 as long as you order some kind of premium meat i.e. either of the beef or, i think, the lamb which they didn't have when we went).  Surprisingly, the best of the 3 was definitely the pork (the cheapest option) - tasty and juicy.  Both iterations of beef were kind of dry.  Also, they had corn tortillas which didn't taste like they came out of the freezer (unlike almost every other corn tortilla I've had in sg).  They weren't bad.  I wonder who makes corn tortillas in Singapore.Oh also they have quite a few different salsas to choose from.  About 6 I think?  I was lost in indecision and the girl helpfully offered to put on what she suggested would go with each meat.  Had the mango salsa (no spice) with the pork - quite nice!  The other two were the Verde (not very spicy) and... a red one.  I forget which.  It also wasn't very spicy. My girlfriend found the guacamole somewhat salty.  I don't usually have guac so hard for me to comment on that myself.One final thing - we were looking forward to chocolate and churros there but the owner said they were still "perfecting the recipe" for the churros.  Sad.  Price-wise, it was pretty reasonable especially for downtown.  My girlfriend's mini burrito was $8 I think.  The 3 Tacos were $13 plus $2 for the premium meat, and they added 10% service charge - I have no idea why they charge service charge when you order and pay at the counter.  Portions were not huge by any means.Overall, not the best ever but not bad.  I would go back again for some decent mid-priced Tacos, especially the chicken and the pork.

photos.caption: Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore. 3 tacos ($13 + $2 cuz I had the more expensive beef). Pork, beef and beef. Pork was def the best of the 3.

-jRbqETXlMfxS7ZrgiA62A.text: I don't know, man.Mex out is like a friend that you want to maintain relations with, but the drama continues to ensue and you're left wondering whether it's worth it or not.I really want to be friends, Mex Out, I really do! It's been over a year, and this time I tried the small 10-inch chicken burrito (to save money and calories.) Luckily it wasn't as salty as last time but the chicken was a bit too dry for me, and the rice seemed like it was drenched in tomato sauce and slightly undercooked. At least they set up the burrito right, as I got a taste of all ingredients during each bite (unlike Baja Fresh, which really needs learn the basics of burrito making.)Maybe I'm just ordering the wrong thing. Should I be doing tacos? Barbacoa burritos? Carne Asada burritos? I still love the branding and the vibe, and it's definitely a nice place to chill and have a beer... but I have yet to find the one food item that'll make me add one more star.

photos.caption: Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore. Oops, looks like someone got untucked!
Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore. 10 inch small burrito, $9.90
Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore. Plentiful napkins, straws, and utensils in an empty 2.8 kg can of green tomatoes

Qx8yWzYAtRWAY5KJXvnXQA.text: For a place that's thousands of miles away from Mexico with limited mexican food option, Mex Out is decent. It's by no means authentic and it's not even trying to be. I agree that it reminded me of Chipotle.I like getting either the salad bowl or the rice bowl - the latter being if i'm ESPECIALLY HUNGRY because it's kinda a lot of food. The you can mix and match your own meat, beans, sauces, and whatever add-ons you want to your dish. Whatever you do, go with the pork - it's good. For sauces, I like their mango salsa and picante.And that's all really. I've been going here for my mexican fix because of the convenient location (it's in the CBD). But truth to be told Singapore is still in the market for a good, proper mexican food.

photos.caption: Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore. Salad bowl with pulled pork

o5OGz8PLFdM4vswA-L52Zw.text: Well the first thing I thought about when going to this place is whether it would be even close to Chipotle in the US.  Whoever opened this place obviously thought chipotle was a good business model. While I cant say its as good in the burrito department they have some good food. Its more of a quick eats type place. You can pick between a burrito, taco, salad and nachos.  Then you add on a variety of toppings. The rice was ok but I miss the lime cilantro rice from chipotle.  The toppings were good, the veggies were very tasty and they had a variety of good salsas.  With the meat and beans added in it became a bit soupy so I think they should do a better job at draining it before adding it in to the burrito.  You can also get beers, margaritas and tequilas which seems fine but not when your heading back to work, maybe after.   Its a nice place, good service, not really chipotle but the closest youll get in singapore for sure.  Definitely worth checking out so if you like mexican food give it a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore

z-1y40VwPbfewWawoyfdfg.text: There are few Mexican restaurants in Singapore. However, be that as it may, Mex Out has just shot to the top of the list. Yes for all you Singaporeans searching for good Mexican food,  the search is officially over. For sure designed to be a Chipotle style restaurant it really does hit the bullseye.Very fresh food, great flavors, chips and salsa on the money, 7$ Negra Modelo's and margaritas during happy hour. What's not to like?Just about perfect.

photos.caption: Photo of Mex Out - Singapore, Singapore. Mex Out

r8YOhWKnS7OwuVwzE1gUYw.text: Chipotle gets it right on so many levels I was excited to try this Chipotle knock-off.  After waiting in live for bit I ordered a salad bowl with black beans, chicken & guacamole. The beans were under-cooked and the guacamole was browning and starting to turn. I had to scrape around it to avoid it because it tasted so bad. Plus, at about S$12.50 it cost more than I would have paid at Chipotle for a similar dish. Bottom line: its a Chipotle copy cat that charges more for lower quality.

31RyzCgS0JyUL8sOuf9AdQ.text: I'm looking for the best Mexican in Singapore (no, no estoy hablando de ti Memo!)--this place is trying really hard to be good and I tried really hard to like it.  So let's get down to the neeety greeety: As soon as you walk in, you're thinking "okay, this could be good".  The bottles of Valentina hot sauce on the tables mean that somebody knows what's up.  On the menu board "carne asada" and "cochinita pibil" jump right out at you.  And then it starts to go downhill.  The staff seems confused, like the place just opened, and like even they aren't really sure what should go on those tortillas next.  The carne asada was okay but really salty and the cochinita pibil, while tender, was pretty bland.  My suggestions for the chef: we're too far from the States (Mexican and American): don't let people choose what to put on their tortilla.  I know what I'm doing in a Mexican place and even I got confused with the cabbage, lettuce, beans, cheese (please tell me you don't let people put cheese on their tacos!!!).  Lose the chafing dishes, give us two or three standard tacos and one or two standard burritos to choose from, make them delicious and serve them hot!

WCVSAoQZUBfCtMXRYW-rLQ.text: Haaaaa. I seem to be saying this a lot but I really wanted to like this place. I received the invite to their opening party a while back and didn't go. But I was so excited at the prospect of a burrito place that was "chipotle-like" according to a certain publication that I forwarded the info to a number of my friends working in the area. Side note, I've learnt to not trust recommendations from said publication because I've had several blah experiences based on their rec's to date.Anyway I went to Mex Out yesterday with my friend, J, who was/is my bestie from our time at UVA. She had the tacos and I had a burrito with cochinita pibil, pinto & black beans, sour cream, lettuce, 2 salsa's and guacamole (why do I have to pay $2 more for guac?). The portions were decent if you consider how much an average meal costs in Raffles Place (or at least that's what I keep telling myself everyday).How'd it go? Uh it was really salty. At first I thought hmm maybe it's just the beans. Took that out and ate the pork with the rest of the ingredients...nope still salty. I eat hawker food pretty regularly (hello salty chwee kuay at ghim moh) so it's not like I had some salt sensitivity issues. So I still finished my burrito like a good Asian person but boy did I have that icky "man I need some water" feeling afterwards. Actually now that I've read some of the reviews below, I realize I'm not the only one who felt their food was salty. Oh well, maybe I'll be back for the alcohol?

9wjUbURtRj90Gcw5DtOuZw.text: I decided to stop in for some mexican style food while in Singapore. Having lived in SF for a while I get cravings for a burrito but most mexican restaurants in asia just can't get it right. Mex Out nailed it. While it has references to Chipotle, Mex Out has a bit more style and a cool vibe.  The food quality was great and the flavoring combinations were well above what all the negative reviews here would have me think.  I'd recommend this place to anyone (unless that person hates mexican food... but who can hate good mexican food??)  But don't just take my word for it, go in and check the place out.I did have one complaint... no horchatta.  But this is singapore, and I honestly can't see horchatta selling her. (guess I need to go back to the American Continent for that.)

NOX5x14uAxpbGjHFgx4iCQ.text: I've been to Mex Out twice, and while I while readily volunteer that I always end up there a little past peak lunch hour, I've never, ever, had warm food. The filling, in addition to being "not generous", has just always been cold. Between my colleagues and I, we've tried both tacos and the burritos, and Mex Out has disappointed both times.This is my first one star review, but I've never dined at anywhere that I could say with such certainty. I'm never going back.

ZxcReOTCLV-b32gmGrYMNQ.text: The pork and guac were good. They were not kidding when they named the mini burrito, it was about a third of the size of the normal burrito. It was almost a taco. I think the black beans were also too salty and the margarita was mostly ice.

D4rFX7nU4UEQjrElDUtsNw.text: Good spot for a casual bite. I met a gf for a few drinks and some eats. Beware, there's not many options... beer, margaritas and sangria, but happy hour from 6-8pm is a decent bargain. Table service isn't really an option, you order at the counter so it's very cafeteria style. We had some corn chips and guacamole... the corn chips were freshly fried and the guac was chunky and fresh. Decent snack for $6.We both had the rice-bowl (effectively the burrito without the tortilla) which was a good size and well tasty... go down the cafeteria chain and choose your beans, your protein, the salad, and your salsa (lots to choose from). Guac and cheese costs extra (which I don't agree with, but whatever). The tacos looked like a good share option, as do the nachos. Service was mixed... the guys were friendly, the sole girl looked like she wanted to be anywhere but behind the counter. Maybe some edgy music could give the place a bit more vibe? It was lacking in atmosphere somewhat but if you're just after something tasty to fill the belly, then maybe this is for you. I'd go back for a quick bite... or maybe go for drinks at one of the numerous neighbouring bars and then go to Mexout to soak up the alcohol!

ddGoV8zKpo4JFWfe-xBjBg.text: I had such high expectations from Mex Out especially after hearing about their Chipotle-like concept. Similar to another reviewer, I am a native Texan, born and raised. So I have sorely been missing quality Tex-Mex in Singapore. I was ready to make this place one of my regulars. Until that is I actually went there to eat. I discovered the only thing about this place similar to Chipotle is the assembly line approach to making your food. I ordered a burrito and it was extremely pricy for what you get. It was filled primarily with rice and little meat. The guacamole was not guacamole...Maybe it was just a bad batch that day but the avocado wasn't even ripe making it hard and chunky to eat :( sad to say, I am still searching for tasty tex-mex in Singapore...

EbsXVR9uFZCpmtjY2QmksQ.text: Great decor, great taste, affordable food. I recommend the mango pineapple salsa with the cochinita pibil. My mouth is watering now just thinking about it. MexOut may have had its hiccups in the beginning but I think they've really made an effort to listen to reviews and improve. Definitely give it another try if you've been disappointed.

tAa0V_tme3vY7qmQ4NCvTA.text: If you want Mexican food in a more casual setting similar to Chipotle, this is a good spot.  The flavors are authentic, the ingredients are fresh, and the prices are decent compared to other Mexican places around town.  I had a chicken salad bowl that was pretty decent, but my friend's babacoa was far tastier.  And the side of guacamole was  plentiful and delicious.
